recovered from diseased strawberry crowns in Japan. In pathogenicity tests it can also cause a low level of disease on rose (Rosaceae)

from soil beneath a declining mature Quercus robur and from the littoral zone of a lake with Phragmites australis and Salix alba as dominants, in pathogenicity tests P. gallica was only weakly aggressive to Q. robur and S. alba, and non-pathogenic to Phragmites australis (Phytophthora database).

Thirteen genera in 11 families, including Malus spp. (Rosaceae); possibly also on Pinaceae seedlings including Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Abies spp., and Tsuga mertensiana (mountain hemlock).
Pathogenic on Patersonia sp., Xanthorrhoea preissii, Hakea sp.and Pinus radiata.
12 genera in 11 families including Hevea (rubber Euphorbiaceae) Rhododendron (Ericaceae) and Cocos nucifera (coconut Arecaceae) (Phytophthora database).
Primarily Citrus spp. (Rutaceae); on 11 genera in 9 families (Phytophthora database). Kalmia in Scotland, Chamaecyparis in England (DC database)
Quercus, Castanopsis, Carpinus and Cupressus spp. In pathogenicity trials it was capable of causing lesions on twigs of Juglans regia.
Natural host unknown, but isolated from a Citrus sp. orchard (Rutaceae). Inoculated hosts include Malus domestica (apple, Rosaceae) and Cucumis sativus (cucumber, Cucurbitaceae).
Thus far it has not been associated with diseased plant material.

leaf and stem necrosis on Rhododendron catawbiense and collar rot of Kalmia latifolia. It also causes seedling damping-off of cucumber (Cucumis sativus cv. Orient Express) and root rots of azaleas (Rhododendron Kurume hybrid cv. Hershey’s Red). It also infected the roots of dusty miller (Senecio bicolor subsp. cineraria cv. Silver Dust), tomato (Solanum lycopersicum cv. Homestead) and pepper (Capsicum annuum) plants. In addition, it can enter through wounds and cause fruit rot of peppers and tomatoes.

Late blight of potato and tomato. Overwinters in tubers. Several races occur. Also causes leaf blights and, rarely, damping off, flower, and fruit blight in a wide range of hosts (Phytophthtora database). Severe pathogen of potato (Solanum tuberosum) and tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum) and can lead to 100% crop loss under conditions favorable for disease development and in the absence of fungicide
Rhododendron sp. (Ericaceae). Able to infect Malus domestica (apple, Rosaceae) and Cucumis sativus (cucumber, Cucurbitaceae) fruits when inoculated
Plants in multiple families, including Aesculus hippocastanum (chestnut, Sapindaceae), Salix (willow, Salicaceae), Olea (olive, Oleaceae) and Vitis (grapevine, Vitaceae).

Solanum melongena (eggplant); Solanum tuberosum (potato), Lycopersicon esculentum (tomato), all Solanaceae, and Beta vulgaris (sugar beet, Chenopodiaceae) are infected when inoculated. Reports on Myrtus (Myrtaceae) are Phytophthora italica.
pathogenic to azaleas and some vegetables such as tomato, pepper, and eggplant.

Fagus sylvatica. It has also been isolated from similar lesions on Quercus robur and Liriodendron tulipifera. Rhododendron ponticum, Magnolia spp., Pieris formosa, Gevuina avellana, Camellia spp. and Michelia doltsopa, and leaf and shoot dieback of Q. ilex.

Alnus glutinosa, Fraxinus excelsior, Prunus spp. and Salix matsudana. in laboratory pathogenicity assays it proved to be moderately aggressive to stems/ twigs of Betula pendula, Carpinus betulus, Fagus sylvatica, Quercus petraea and Salix alba.

Chamaecyparis lawsoniana (Lawson cypress aka Port Orford cedar, Cupressaceae), Chamaecyparis obtusa, Chamaecyparis pisifera, Thuja occidentalis, Thuja plicata, rarely Taxus brevifolia (Pacific yew, Taxaceae). DNA finding on Juniperus sabina in UK. Published reports on hosts other than Cupressaceae and Taxaceae thought to be mis-identifcations (See Green & Webber; Pest Risk Analysis for Phytophthora lateralis).
Pathogenic on Xanthorrhoea preissii, Banksia sp. and Casuarina obesa.
Various plant families including Hevea spp. (rubber, Euphorbiaceae).
Medicago sativa (alfalfa), Onobrychis viciifolia (sainfoin), Cicer arietinum (chickpea) (Fabaceae). Also reported on Prunus mahaleb (cherry, Rosaceae).
Theobroma cacao (cacao, Sterculiaceae). Also reported from Irvingia sp. (Irvingiaceae).
Cucumis sativus (cucumber, Cucurbitaceae). Also reported from Citrullus lanatus (Cucurbitaceae) and Pistacia vera (Anacardiaceae).

Associated with several taxa. Pathogenic toward Eucalyptus gomphocephala, E. marginata, Agonis flexuosa. Implicated in decline of Eucalyptus gomphocephala. Numerous other hosts including Banksia attenuata, B. grandis, B. littoralis, B. menziesii, B. prionotes, Bossiaea sp., Conospermum sp., Gastrolobium spinosum, Leucopogon verticillatus, Xanthorrhoea gracilis, Patersonia sp., Podocarpus drouyniana, Quercus petraea and Pinus radiata.
Rose stems in Japan. In pathogenicity tests it can also cause a low level of disease on strawberry
necrotic lesions of Umbellularia californica, Arctostaphylos spp., and Sequoia sempervirens. It has also been recovered from bark cankers of Lithocarpus densiflorus and Quercus agrifolia.
Wide host range: 255 genera in 90 families

nursery plants and soil underneath diseased Aesculus hippocastanum.  leaf tissue of Kalmia latifolia, substrate underneath Pieris and from soil samples underneath Aesculus hippocastanum exhibiting disease symptoms.Pathogenicity tests have confirmed K. latifolia, A. hippocastanum, Rhododendron catawbiense and Pieris japonica as hosts

Ficus carica (Iran), Pistacia vera crowns, branches and surrounding soil (Iran and USA), and Prunus dulcis (Greece) (phytophthora database). Medicago sativa (Leguminosae) (Q bank).

Phaseolus lunatus (also reported as P. limensis) (lima beans, Fabaceae). Capable of infecting plants from other families after inoculation (Erwin & Ribeiro 1996). Also reported from Phaseolus vulgaris (common bean).
Pine, beech (Jung et al. 2009), ornamentals and vegetables  (Hong et al. 2008) (phytophthora database)

Abies alba, Alnus glutinosa, Alnus incana, Acer platanoides, Acer pseudoplatanus, Acer saccharum, Aesculus hippocastanum, Carpinus betulus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Quercus robur, Quercus petraea, Quercus rubra, Rhododendron spp., Syringa vulgaris, Tilia spp., Tsuga canadensis (phytophthtora database) Acer saccharum (Sapindaceae); Corynocarpus laevigatus (Corynocarpaceae); Fagus sylvatica (Fagaceae); Rhododendron hybrid (Ericaceae); soil with Alnus glutinosa root (Q bank)

P. pluvialis was recovered from baited streams, soil and canopy drip in the mixed tanoak (Notholithocarpus densiflorus)-Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) forest in Curry County, Oregon, USA. We have found it in two additional streams in western Oregon (Clear Creek, lower west slope of north Oregon Cascades and Yachats River, lower west slope of central Oregon Coast Range). It has been found only rarely associated with twig and stem cankers on tanoak. We have not found P. pluvialis associated with any other plant host.

Recovered from soil around declining alder trees but in laboratory tests was slightly pathogenic to alder twigs and not pathogenic to trunks of several tree species (phytophthora database). Alnus glutinosa (Betulaceae) (Q bank).
Principal host: Allium spp. (Liliaceae); also 5 other genera in 5 families. Not on Brassicaceae; this is a distinct species Phytophthora brassicae (Phytophthora datbase). Leeks (DC database).

Quercus spp., Fagus sylvatica, Alnus glutinosa and other hardwood species (Phytophthtora database) Larix (Anna Harris). Pieris, Magnolia (DC database). Nothofagusis in Britain (Scanu et al 2012), Castanea sativa in Sardinia (Scanu et al 2010) Fagus sylvatica in Central italy (Motta et al 2003). Umbellularia californica in the USA. Vaccinium myrtillus (Beales et al 2009)
Infects Ilex aquifolium and Quercus spp. in inoculation tests.
Quercus spp. (Fagaceae) (Phytophthtora database). Medicago sativa (Leguminosae) (Q bank).
At least 26 genera in 17 families, including Rhododendron spp. (Ericaceae) and Quercus spp. (Fagaceae).
Zantedeschia spp. (Araceae). Also Robinia (Fabaceae), Asparagus (Asparagaceae), Daucus carota (carrot, Apiaceae), and Lycopersicon esculentum (tomato, Solanaceae) (Erwin & Ribeiro 1996).

Glycine max (soybeans), Lupinus spp. (lupine) (Fabaceae); also reported from six other genera in five families (Phytophthora database).

Chrysanthemum spp., Verbena, Santolina (Asteraceae) (Phytophthora database). Bacopa sp. (Plantaginaceae); Chrysanthemum frutescens (Compositae); Chrysanthemum leucanthemum (Compositae); Verbena sp. (Verbenaceae), Argyranthemum frutescens, Bacopa, Leucanthemum vulgare,Verbena (Q-bank).

Quercus robur, Quercus petraea (Fagaceae) (Jung et al 2002).

Vigna unguiculata (= Vigna sinensis, Fabaceae), Vigna angularis (=Phaseolus angularis, Fabaceae, sometimes referred to Phytophthora vignae f.sp. adzukicola). Malus domestica (apple, Rosaceae) fruits can be infected when inoculated. Reports from a few other taxa (Phytophthora database).
